title: How many days in total are patients delayed and how has this changed?
analysis_commentary:
Despite individual monthly fluctuations, the total number of days patients are delayed per month has increased over time from 109,918 in August 2010, to 134,508 in February 2015 (a 22% increase) and it reached a maximum of 151,093 delayed days in January 2015.

There is also a fairly consistent steep increase in the number of delayed days occurring from April 2014. We assume that this is not solely because of the recent increases observed in the number of patients delayed.
• the recent increase in the number of patients being delayed begins around January 2014, without immediate change to the pattern in the number of delayed days.
• our previous analysis of this information up to April 2014 showed that despite there being an overall decrease from August 2010 in the number of patients being delayed there was still an overall increase in the number of delayed days, which we attributed to an increase in the average length of delays. So even before the increase in number of patients being delayed they was already an observed increase in people waiting longer.
data_source: NHS England, Delayed transfer of care
